org.jpws.pwslib.data
Class PwsFile

java.lang.Object
  org.jpws.pwslib.data.PwsRecordList
      org.jpws.pwslib.data.PwsFile
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
public class PwsFile
extends PwsRecordList
implements java.lang.Cloneable

Top level structure of this library to represent a PasswordSafe (PWS) database file.

This class is an extension of a record list (PwsRecordList), hence data of all records is kept in memory, eventually causing restrictions on the amount of records that can be kept in an application. The extension deals with all definitions required to represent or create a "persistent state" (PWS file) of a record list on an external medium. It also allows to define a set of up to 255 "header fields" which are data elements on a list generic level.

Persistent State

The persistent state is defined/identified by a quadruple: i) a filename (filepath), ii) a related IO-context (application adapter), iii) an access passphrase, and iv) a file format version. Using ApplicationAdapter is a fairly abstract conception to access peripheral media, which can be easily adapted to any user context. The full definition of a persistent state is however not mandatory to use an instance of PwsFile. This class ensures that there are always valid settings for application adapter and file format.

File IO:

Persistent states are accessed through data streams which are made available by application adapters. The concrete handling of file-IO and data formatting is handled by class PwsFileFactory. To obtain an instance of this class from its persistent state, use the static PwsFileFactory.loadFile() methods. To create a persistent state use the save() or saveCopy() methods of this class when all required parameters for the persistent state are available. If a loaded file was of a different format version, or some indication of potential data loss occurred during loading, the next save will make an attempt to preserve the existing file by adding a name extention ".old".

File Formats

This class now supports reading and writing of all three historical, major file format versions of PasswordSafe. The following policy is adopted concerning these formats. Files loaded from a persistent state (via PwsFileFactory) feature the format version of the persistent state. New instances (not loaded) feature the latest available format version. File saving produces an output format version as currently set in the PwsFile object. At any time the user can modify the file format setting of an instance without restrictions. Downgrading a file version will, however, likely result in loss of record data that is not supported in the older format.

Header Fields

Since library version 2-0-0 (and PWS format version 3) a facility for up to 255 data fields, each of free length and type, is supported by PwsFile. This is a handy way of making file generic information available which may be application specific. Through getHeaderFields() the user gets hold of a HeaderFieldList containing elements of type PwsRawField. This list can be mined for and manipulated with data; however it will only be stored on a persistent state in file format V3. There are several reserved data fields defined by PWS and JPWS. The user of this library should not define proprietary fields in the range 0x00 .. 0x7F.

User Options:

User options take the form of a text string and are now stored as an element of the header field list (field-ID is PwsFileHeaderV3.JPWS_OPTIONS_TYPE). These options are reflected both into V3 and V2 files. For V2 files options also may contain the PasswordSafe Preferences (special options of the program PWS); for V3 files PWS Preferences are stored in a special header field and may be accessed by field-ID PwsFileHeaderV3.PWS_PREFS_TYPE.

Universal Encoding:

As of file format version V3 all text data is stored in universal encoding (UTF-8). File format V2 (which is deprecated) stores text in UTF-8 only if "B 24 1" is contained within the PasswordSafe Preferences, otherwise it uses the current JVM default encoding (which may be locale specific).

See Also:
PwsFileFactory, ApplicationAdapter

Constructor Detail

PwsFile

public PwsFile()
Constructs a new, empty PWS database for the standard IO-context (by default the local file system) but with a void definition of the persistent state. (Note that filepath and passphrase have to be set up before this file can be saved.)

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if no global standard application is available

PwsFile

public PwsFile(DefaultRecordWrapper[] recs)
Constructs a new PWS database with an initial record content as represented by the parameter record wrapper array. Duplicate records in the array are silently ignored; no check for record validity is performed.

Parameters:
recs - array of DefaultRecordWrapper objects; may be null
Since:
0-4-0

               java.lang.String filepath,
               PwsPassphrase userpass)
Constructs a fully defined, empty PWS database with all required references for an external persistent state.

Parameters:
appl - ApplicationAdapter the IO-context used to save the persistent state of this file
filepath - the full filepath specification for the persistent state
userpass - a PwsPassphrase object defining the access passphrase used to encrypt the content
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any param is void

Method Detail

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
Returns a shallow clone of this file structure (PwsFile). File-ID number is modified to be unique and any registered listeners are removed from the clone. The stored passphrase is a copy; UUID is the same.

Overrides:
clone in class PwsRecordList
Returns:
object of type PwsFile
Since:
2-1-0

copy

public java.lang.Object copy()
Returns a deep clone of this file structure (PwsFile). All records of the returned list are copies of the original. File-ID number is modified to be unique and any registered listeners are removed from the clone. The stored passphrase is a copy; UUID is the same.

Overrides:
copy in class PwsRecordList
Returns:
object of type PwsFile
Since:
2-1-0

replaceFrom

public void replaceFrom(PwsFile f)
This method replaces entire content of this file, including all settings, by the contents of the parameter file. Works as a shallow clone of the record list and shares identity with the parameter file.

Parameters:
f - PwsFile new content for this file

getCharset

public java.lang.String getCharset()
Returns the activated character set used to encode text strings on the persistent state. (The charset is "Utf-8" for V3 file format (fixum) or for V2 format if "B 24 1" is present in user options. It is the VM default character set otherwise.)

Returns:
String charset name
Since:
2-0-0

setFormatVersion

public void setFormatVersion(int value)
Sets the format version number for the file. This value determines the technical file format of the persistent state of this file. By default (for a new instance) the latest available format version is active. This is (normally) a fast returning operation.

Parameters:
value - the file format code (use one of the values defined in class Global) or 0 for latest format
Since:
2-0-0

getBlockedDataSize

public long getBlockedDataSize(int format)
Returns the size of the data block required to store the content of this database on a persistent state. (This takes into respect the general file formating rules of a PWS file of the specified format.) This is a relatively expensive operation as it walks through analysing all records with each call.

Parameters:
format - the file format version of the persistent state
Returns:
int required (blocked) data space
Since:
2-0-0

save

public void save()
          throws java.io.IOException,
                 ApplicationFailureException
Writes this file to its persistent state in the linked IO-context. This method requires that the persistent state of this file is fully defined. After successful operation, the "modified" flag is reset to false. This method does nothing if the "modified" flag is already false.

The persistent state of a file is defined by application adapter, filepath and access passphrase.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the required parameters for the persistent state are undefined
java.io.IOException - if an IO-error occurs
ApplicationFailureException - if the IO-context fails to render an output stream

saveCopy

public UUID saveCopy(ApplicationAdapter app,
                     java.lang.String filepath)
              throws java.io.IOException,
                     ApplicationFailureException
Writes a copy of this file to a specified file of a specified medium, applying the same passphrase as is defined for this file. The copy will own a different UUID identifier.

Parameters:
app - the application context in which the target file will be created; if null then the same application is referred to as is defined for this file
filepath - the file name specification (relative to app) for the target file
Returns:
UUID the file identifier value of the copy or null if unavailable
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if filepath or the file passphrase are not defined
java.io.IOException - if an IO-error occurs
ApplicationFailureExeption - if the IO-context fails to render an output stream
ApplicationFailureException

saveCopy

public UUID saveCopy(ApplicationAdapter app,
                     java.lang.String filepath,
                     PwsPassphrase pass)
              throws java.io.IOException,
                     ApplicationFailureException
Writes a copy of this file to a specified file of a specified medium, allowing to setup a different access passphrase for the copy. The copy will own a different UUID identifier.

Parameters:
app - the application context in which the target file will be created; if null then the same application is referred to as defined for this file
filepath - the file name specification (valid for app) for the target file
pass - an optional passphrase for the copy; if null the passphrase of this file is used
Returns:
UUID the file identifier value of the copy or null if unavailable
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if filepath or the file passphrase are not defined
java.io.IOException - if an IO-error occurs
ApplicationFailureExeption - if the IO-context fails to render an output stream
ApplicationFailureException
Since:
0-3-1

saveCopy

public UUID saveCopy(ApplicationAdapter app,
                     java.lang.String filepath,
                     PwsPassphrase pass,
                     int format,
                     boolean preserveUUID)
              throws java.io.IOException,
                     ApplicationFailureException
Writes a copy of this file to a specified file of a specified medium, allowing to setup a different passphrase and a different file format version for the copy .

Parameters:
app - the application context in which the target file will be created; if null then the same application is referred to as defined for this file
filepath - the file name specification (valid for app) for the target file
pass - an optional passphrase for the copy; if null the passphrase of this file is used
format - the target file format version or 0 for this file's actual format setting
preserveUUID - if true the existing UUID will be the same in the copy otherwise a new one is created; V3 only
Returns:
UUID the file identifier value of the saved file or null if unavailable
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if filepath or the file passphrase are not defined
java.io.IOException - if an IO-error occurs
ApplicationFailureExeption - if the IO-context fails to render an output stream
ApplicationFailureException

getUserOptions

public java.lang.String getUserOptions()
Returns a text String with file specific options set by the user.

The policy of this value is the following: for format V2 files it represents the same data field that is also used by PasswordSafe (PWS). For format V3 it represents a JPWS specific data field (which is not an element of the PWS canon). The PWS specific preferences of a V3 file can be obtained by getHeaderFields().getField(PwsFileHeaderV3.PWS_PREFS_TYPE).getString("utf-8"). V1 format does not support an option string.

Returns:
String with user options; empty string if undefined

setUserOptions

public void setUserOptions(java.lang.String options)
Sets the user options for this file.

Note concerning the persistent state: For V2 files this will set the PWS preferences header field. For V3 files it will set a JPWS specific field (which is not an element of the PWS canon). The PWS preferences (String x) of a V3 file can be set by getHeaderFields().setField(new PwsRawField(PwsFileHeaderV3.PWS_PREFS_TYPE,x.getBytes("utf-8"))). V1 format does not support an option string.

Parameters:
options - String, may be null to clear an assignment

setPassphrase

public void setPassphrase(PwsPassphrase userpass)
Sets the user passphrase for the encryption of this file (access passphrase). There are no controls on the quality of the passphrase value used. (Note that the empty passphrase is allowed.)

Parameters:
userpass - PwsPassphrase, the access passphrase to be used on persistent states. Use null to clear

public boolean hasResource()
Whether there exists a complete persistent file definition for this instance.

Returns:
true if and only if there is an application adapter defined and there is a filepath defined
Since:
0-3-0

getHeaderFields

public HeaderFieldList getHeaderFields()
Returns the operational header field list of this file. Use the returned object to perform your header field operations. (This list is always present but will be saved to a persistent state only in file format version V3.)

Returns:
HeaderFieldList
Since:
2-0-0

Parameters:
value - String formatted UUID list (may be null)

isChecksumVerified

public boolean isChecksumVerified()
Whether the checksum of a V3 file has been verified OK during loading of the persistent state. (True for V2 and V1 or new files.)

Returns:
true if and only if this file is a V3 file AND load checksum is verified OK
Since:
2-0-0

setSecurityLoops

public void setSecurityLoops(int loops)
Sets the amount of security caclulation loops valid for the access shield of this database. The parameter value will be corrected to comply with minimum 2048 and maximum 4194304. (The property "SecurityLoops" is only meaningful for V3 files.)

Parameters:
loops - amount of calculation loops
Since:
2-1-0

getSecurityLoops

public int getSecurityLoops()
Returns the amount of security caclulation loops valid for the access shield of this database. (The property "SecurityLoops" is only meaningful for V3 files.)

Since:
2-1-0

getSignature

public byte[] getSignature()
Renders a content signature value for this PWS file. Returns a SHA-256 checksum which is a sum-up of all its records' signatures plus all its header field values. This value is considered individual to an instance. (It may be assumed - although there is no guarantee - that this value is identical over different releases of this software package and different sessions of a program running this package.)

Overrides:
getSignature in class PwsRecordList
Returns:
byte[] 32 byte signature value (SHA-256 digest)
Since:
2-1-0
